  654. Well worth the money! I am newbie at waxing and I bought this kit mainly for my underarms. I was never completely blessed with the &#34;hairless gene&#34; and I after several years of constantly having to shave my armpit hair, I decided to give this waxing kit a try and I am so happy I did. Trust me, this stuff is super easy to use and it even comes with an instructional dvd that will give you really good pointers for waxing. I got tired of having to shave my underarms almost everyday and this gigi brazilian waxing kit is a gift from the hairless fairy. Waxing your armpits with this kit gives me beautiful hairless armpits for almost 3 weeks. I have tried waxing my legs with this and my legs was hairless for almost 5 weeks. I just have to warn you though that if you are waxing your underarms for the first time, it will be painful so take a tylenol/advil/etc. if you have a low tolerance to pain. As for leg hairs, its really painless almost similar to band-aid being removed from your skin. One last tip, proper disinfecting is super important because waxing open up your pores so you really need to buy an oil/lotion with disinfecting properties like tea tree oil or lavender oil. I bought an organic tea tree oil and it works great. Bottom line, Yes I highly recommend this product.
  655. I've never waxed anything before so I did tons of research and watched at least a dozen videos on how to do it when I came across this kit. I struggled between this one and the Pro kit but found this one to be more of what I wanted.<br /><br />This wax comes<br />-with the DVD (I thought everyone else reviewing here was just exaggerating when they said it was graphic but dear lord the first thing I see is a vagina),<br />-a 14 oz can of hard wax (you DO NOT need strips with this. it hardens and becomes a strip itself which I found so incredibly awesome),<br />-two little bottles of product,<br />-a lovely wax warmer,<br />-one clean collar to put around your can of wax for easy clean up,<br />- and three different sizes of applicators.<br /><br />Hard wax is definitely my go to type because I like the thought of saving money not having to buy rolls of muslin. The only thing that I wasn't happy with was that the two bottles of product leaked all over everything. The good news is that everything is wrapped securely in plastic so nothing got on the wax, dvd, applicators, or warmer.<br /><br />Things I recommend going out and buying before you wax any body parts:<br />-baby powder (keeps the wax from sticking to skin. I hated the pre-epilation oil. Really not a fan of oils in general)<br />-Some clean collars for your warmer (the kit comes with one but if it gets messy quickly then you'll need more)<br />-possibly a trimmer (if you are braving anywhere below the belt and your hair is too long a trimmer is a godsend. I ran out and bought a $10 razor/trimmer)<br />-Popsicle sticks. The kit comes with different sizes but they're angled and I found that having some round sticks improves my application.<br />-Aloe Vera. After you wax the area is tender and needs to be soothed. I use aloe vera often so I always have some on hand.<br /><br />I've only waxed my upper lip, between my eyebrows, and my arms. I never had any problem with messes or anything like that. I didn't have any problem with pain either. (take some pain killers 30 minutes before you wax if you're worried)<br /><br />Some tips:<br />-I heated the wax on high for about an hour until it becomes very very runny. Then I set it to low or about 20 minutes to half an hour so that the consistency is like a glue. Check the temperature on your wrist to make sure it's comfortable for you. I like my wax warm but not excruciatingly hot.<br />-Apply thinly. You can always add more layers if the wax is too brittle.<br />-If wax gets stuck on nails, hair, or skin use baby oil, vegetable oil, or olive oil to gently rub it away. Key word: GENTLY.<br /><br />Wish you the best of luck and hope this review helps!any problem with pain either. (take some pain killers 30 minutes before you wax if you're worried)<br /><br />Some tips:<br />-I heated the wax on high for about an hour until it becomes very very runny. Then I set it to low or about 20 minutes to half an hour so that the consistency is like a glue. Check the temperature on your wrist to make sure it's comfortable for you. I like my wax warm but not excruciatingly hot.<br />-Apply thinly. You can always add more layers if the wax is too brittle.<br />-If wax gets stuck on nails, hair, or skin use baby oil, vegetable oil, or olive oil to gently rub it away.   656. Used this the day after It arrived. Waxed my armpits! Fairly easy. I watched the DVD witch explains alot of the issues previous customers have had. Common sense dictates to watch the DVD if you have no prior knowledge or experience. I watched it twice. It did help! I did my pits, and tried to do the back of my thigh. This is where i noticed that the wax consistency is crucial to a perfect wax. Num 1: trim!! If you dont it will hurt like a M.F. Num 2: one you eat up the wax and its all &#34;liquified&#34; (extremely thin consistency) turn it off and wait about 10 minutes. The wax should begin to solidify a bit, thicker consistency. This makes a big difference. Trust me i learned it the hadd way. I put a thin coating of wax on my leg and i couldnt get it off. The worst part is that it was on the fatty tissue, so it hurt! :'( well at least i suffered and i can pass on my experience unto you.

  668. Love the set - I had never waxed myself before getting this warmer but after enduring too many cramped hands and crossed eyes trying to tweeze my brows (not to mention all the pain from shaving my bikini line week after week in the summer months) I sprung for the kit.<br /><br />The DVD, while...explicit in its detail, was very helpful with the technique tips - and the reviews here that say to turn the unit on high for about 15 minutes to partially dissolve the wax and then lower it to low and flip the wax \\"puck\\" over are right on - if you leave it on high and try to start waxing, the wax is too hot for your skin and too thin to do an effective job. If you leave it on low it will take a good hour to dissolve all the wax. It should be a caramel-like consistency. When the wax doesn't \\"grab\\" your finger when you tap it and feels slightly firm, it's ready to pull off.<br /><br />If you've ever tweezed or had someone wax for you, you know it isn't painless - but I'll say that this is about as pain-free as waxing gets. I barely feel it on my eyebrows, and it's bearable on my bikini line. I had a full Brazilian with the cloth strips once and it was the most painful experience of my young life - I wish I had known about hard wax back then. I'm still not hardcore enough (or perhaps my hair isn't thin and sparse enough) to endure a full Brazilian with this thing, but that's just me.<br /><br />I only use the oil on my bikini line - it makes my face break out really bad. Haven't really used the cooling gel - I'm too hardcore. (I jest, I'm really just too scatterbrained to remember it.) I mostly use the largest and smallest sticks.<br /><br />I even brought it to work and did my coworker's eyebrows - they are all so impressed with the economy of this thing that I've converted a few people who were regular salon-goers. For the price of one eyebrow waxing, you can get a full year's worth of regular waxing out of this thing. My mom liked it so much I got one for her for the holidays. (Nothing says Merry Christmas like hair removal, right?)<br /><br />I have waxed brows about 15-20 times with this, done my bikini area 6 times, and I'm still barely 1/3 of the way through the wax. It's a great value!

  673. This product is just what I have been looking for! I have very coarse hair so to be on the safe side I tried it under my armpit. I took off everything! Remember to apply the oil before and bear in mind that your skin will absorb some of it so you have to put enough to compensate especially if you are moving slowly. If your hair is as think as mine, do remember to apply pressure to the spot right after ripping off the wax... it really does help. After I got the hang of it I actually saved time by apply to more that one spot at a time. If you are going to do that a good idea is to apply to the middle of your armpit (side to side) with about a 1/2 inch strip. After you get that bit off you start removing from opposite sides of the spot at the same time. I apply to the middle first to ensure that I have a separation... hope you understand what I mean. I was not too concerned about the direction of hair growth, because I couldnt identify any one direction. Instead I ripped in the direction that was most ergonomic for me. Ensure the wax is not too hot, I wait until it stops dripping quickly and instead start to collect at the bottom of the stick. Don't wait too long though because if cools too much it is difficult to apply because it starts pulling the hairs...ouch!<br /><br />Now to my nether- regions. This I attempted one week later. Ensure you watch the video first, it really helps. You will need a large mirror and a towel to sit on. I did it on my bed and used the pillows for back support. First ensure the hairs are the right length.. about 1/4&#34; or 1/2cm and the same suggestion for the oil applies. Map out the general direction of hair growth ... at least to start out with. I would say start with the sides your bikini line or if the hair goes up to your belly button, start there. I suggest that because it starts to narrow the area. Ensure that when you apply the wax the end of the strip is on bare skin. If you end it in a patch of hair it will hurt a lot when it'stime to rip it off. If you decide to brave this section and require more info... just send me a message.

  695. I bought the items in the kit separately at a Sally Beauty Supply, and the total cost was about $20 more, so Amazon has a great price on this kit! I have never used hard wax before but decided to try it based ln internet research and the good reviews I read on Amazon. I have never had a professional waxing done (it weirds me out), and I have a LOW pain tolerance, so I was very, very happy to discover that a) with this hard wax stuff, a home wax job is easy! and b) moderately painful at most. I have tried DIY soft waxing, with the strips, and I recall that as being much FAR MORE PAINFUL than the hard wax. Definitely read the directions. Definitely try to apply the wax so you have a 'pull tab' of wax..that's what helps reduce the pain, in my experience thus far. (And by that I mean, I have used the wax once, but There is a definite difference in pain between 'with pull tab' vs. 'without pull tab.'). And plan at least an hour of prep before you start waxing..my brand new can of wax needed the full 45-minutes for the initiall melting at the 'high' setting, with another 15minutes at the 'low' setting to cool down enough to apply to my skin. The collars are very useful, not just to keep the warmer clean, but also to have a 'lip' to rest the applicator on. I balanced the applicator so that the 'used' end would hover over the melted wax and the 'clean' end would rest on the collar. Not hard to do at all. I bought the after wax cooling gel and the wax remover stuff....honeslty, once I run out, I'll probably just use aloe vera gel and olive oil, respectively. I did use a damp washcloth after applying the 'wax off' lotion to remove the residual wax. Worked ok. As the wax continued to harden, I found that the rest came off in the shower. I am not entirely convinced that the recommended 'Pre Hon' cleaning stuff is a necessity, but since I bought I'll finish the bottle. My local Sally Beauty Supply didnot have the pre-epilation oil. I'll probably purchase that fromAmazon, as other reviewers said it does help reduce discomfort. Prior to waxing, I showered and used a gentle scrub on the area to exfoliate. I am very pleased by this product and I will definitely use it again! My only complaint thus far, the odor is not noxious, but I'll be happy when it dissipates.

  697. I'll be plain - going to get waxed is a pain. The first time I used this kit, it took a bit. I'd never waxed myself before, in any area, and wasn't quite sure what to do. I had watched the instructional video, but it didn't cover how you were supposed to use your right arm to pull from the left side. After about an hour and a half the first time, I was significantly less red and irritated than when going to the salon. I didn't need to wax again for about a month, and then it was easier as I was more experienced. After the wax was heated up (my only complaint is the amount of time the wax takes to melt, but you'll have that issue with any of the kits), the second, more thorough waxing really only took about half an hour. I got to pick my music, relax in my bathroom, and take a break if I needed to. This IS the only self-waxing kit I've owned, so I can't compare it to others. I can only compare it to the nightmare of a salon. With 2 waxes down, I still have over half of the wax that came in this kit.   703. Let me first say that this was my first experience with waxing. I've normally been a eyebrow pluck and shave kind of girl but I was curious about this kit since waxing can be expensive in the salon.<br /><br />I took note of comments on here that if the wax gets too hot it will drip everywhere so when I heated up the wax I put it on high for 22 minutes and then on low and let it sit for a little while. Make sure to add the collar so the wax doesn't drip on the device. It should be noted that this kit does not need strips as you just pull the wax right off (as a novice I didn't know this and thought maybe the strips were missing from the kit)<br /><br />Now in terms of methods with the wax I found it the most effective to dip the sticks in there, scrape one side and then turn it a couple times to let it cool just a little bit before applying. The wax can get stringy like a glue gun which turning it helps get rid of that. You have to make sure you apply thick enough so it doesn't tear apart when you rip and then to make sure you let it cool otherwise it will be sticky and won't pull the hair properly. Although I did find that if you initially applied a section too thin you could apply a little more on top of it. Also, when you apply it helps to have a small amount of wax that doesn't cover hair so that you can grab onto it to pull the strip off.<br /><br />All in all if you have the right temperature and once you get the hang of it you really shouldn't be dripping everywhere and it shouldn't take 3 hours like other people have been saying. Just let the wax heat while you are doing something else and then go to town. I would say... if you are waxing the bikini area to make sure you give it a quick tough pull otherwise it will hurt like crazy. Just make sure you know the more hair you have down there the harder you should pull and the more painful its going to be. So if you have a.... uhhh... hairy animal going on you may want to shave unless you have good pain tolerance. I will say though that this wax does not pull on your skin which does help with the pain factor.<br /><br />If you watch the video that comes with it, be ready to stare straight in the face at a... you know.... a woman's box.<br /><br />Last thing, if you don't want to wax the bikini this wax is very effective with other areas. I used it for underarm hair and it worked great.<br /><br />GOOD LUCK

  707. This is great! I bought this because I had been using a wax pot from Sally Hansen which has apparently stopped making wax refill kits, so I was a little worried about buying this kit. Mostly because I wanted to use it for facial waxing- eyebrows, chin, etc.- and the kit says &#34;body wax&#34;. I do tend to have sensitive skin but I still have to say this is a great buy. The wax pot is HUGE, so you can get a lot of use out of each refill. I personally didn't much like the pre-epilator oil because it caused the wax to not stick to my skin well. I think it would help for waxing newbies who have trouble with the pain, but it caused the wax to not stick to skin or the hair well at all so I skipped the oil. It was actually really good for getting rid of extra wax residue after you're done waxing, though! Definitely remember to turn the wax pot down to low once you've heated the wax to liquid and you're ready to start waxing. Not because it's too hot and will burn your skin, the wax was still alright to touch, but at that level of heat the wax is too runny to effectively do any waxing. Overall, a really great buy and a good value.

I'm so glad I'm a waxer now not a shaver!

  737. Use it daily at work great product.
  738. Love this kit. Not very many reviews from husbands waxing their wives, but here goes. My wife was getting REALLY furry down south, and she agreed to do a Brazilian to spice things up. No way in hell was she going to go to a salon, though, so it was DIY or nothing. I couldn't see her contorting herself for my pleasure, so I volunteered to do the deed. After all, it's my play area :). I did a bit of research and watched a few YouTube videos, along with the video that came with the kit. We set up on a towel on the bed and went to town. I started with small strips first, then worked up to multiple, longer strips-- applying one, letting one cool, and ripping off the third. There was hardly any pain--except when I forgot to start a strip on a hairless area. Now my wife has a really high pain tolerance, so I'm not recommending you do this if it's your first time, and you're really hairy down there. Some of the strips I pulled had HUNDREDS of hairs (with follicles attached!) on them. Most of the stuff I read and saw recommended getting it done professionally first, then using the kit to do maintenance procedures on the fewer, finer hairs that regrow after a few weeks. Tips: Cooler wax is better than hot wax. It should form a ball on the stick after spinning it a couple times. If it runs off the stick, it's too hot. Apply the strip about the thickness of a nickel. Pay attention to direction of hair growth. You ladies grow hair every which way down there. Apply back and forth along and against the direction of growth, but yank against the direction of growth. If you don't pull against the direction of growth, you can end up with hair on the strip, but no follicles. You know what that means: stubble in 48 hours. Oh, and be sure to pull the skin tight while applying the wax. Pull the skin tight when yanking the strip, then press your hand on the area you just denuded. The pressure reduces the pain a lot. Biggie! Make your strips start from an area of no hair. This lets you easily pull up the end to get ready to yank without pulling hairs out in slow motion. I almost got smacked for that one. Try to leave a tag, or thicker spot on the end where you'll be grabbing it. We found that cornstarch worked better (less pain, more hair removed) than the pre-epilation oil. YMMV. Exfoliate and use some sort of growth inhibitor to minimize ingrown hairs. We use Completely Bare Hair Growth Inhibitor, and have not had a single ingrown hair. All in all, it took ~90 minutes to tame the beast. I expect the next session will be half that, now that I have the hang of it. Oh the hardest part for me? Waiting 24 hours to play with my masterpiece ;). ...and why on Earth didn't we do this sooner?
  739. This is an awesome set for at home waxing. The best, most effective wax I've found. Warmer is perfect and adjustable , keeping wax at just the right consistency. Especially perfect for at home maintenance following a professional wax.
  740. Hurts more than other waxes. I've not seen the point of the two liquids that come with it. So far, no benefit to using them.
  741. I got this kit and have been using it for a month now. I have never got a professional Brazilian wax done which I would highly recommend prior to using this product. It is painful like hell when the wax is pulled off and if you have never experienced such pain, it's unlikely you will go ahead with this for more than five minutes. Apply very small amount of wax towards the corner of the area where growth is least so that you don't get stuck in a situation where you won't be able to pull off the wax and the wax hardens and makes matters almost impossible to solve. I take it a very small bit at a time and don't pressure myself into getting it all off on one day. That way I am very happy with the product and don't kill myself in the process.<br />No issues with product itself. The quantities supplied are adequate. The only thing you may need after a few uses are more Gigi collars which help keep things non messy.

  753. Ok, everyone is here because they're tired of paying X amount every month or so to the aesthetician. Cut out the middle man (or woman for this matter), and do it yourself! Waxing is painful whether you do it, or they do it! It's that simple. So long as you maintain your waxing on a pretty regular schedule (for me 4-6 weeks), the pain and hair growth is reduced!<br /><br />I will admit, it took me almost FOUR hours to do my own Brazilian the first time (I had issues with literally ripping at my own skin, finding the right angles, taking breaks, etc.) but the second time I did it, it took me less than an hour!! I love the fact that I can give myself a wax in the comfort of my own dwelling! Plus, I'm saving money-- because let's face it, if you're vain about your appearance, you're vain about your appearance... I don't care if you're married or not!<br /><br />I just had to leave a review because Gigi is the truth! As long as you're familiar with what direction to apply the wax.. pre- & post- prepping... aftercare.. this is a simple process. And if you don't.. well lo' and behold, that's what the fabulous world of Google is for!<br /><br />Finally, yes like others have said, this can get a little messy. I recommend doing it in your bathroom (I sit on the closed toilet seat with a towel under me) with newspaper on the floor so it's an easy clean up. I also choose doing it in the bathroom because there's plenty of mirrors at my disposal. Keep your tweezers (and alcohol to sterilize them) handy for those loose hairs! Lots of sticks come in the packing, and I chose not to buy the extra covers that go around the neck to protect the warmer. I'll probably just use cardboard from discarded boxes once the original cover gets too gunked up! Good luck!!

My biggest issue, though, is that the wax gets very dirty, very quickly.. So my advice to anyone who is looking to do full-leg waxes (or is Italian, or some other ethnicity with thicker, longer hairs) is to buy extra cans of wax to keep on hand. Otherwise you're just using the same wax over and over with all your plucked hairs inside the mixture- not pretty and I would guess over time, not as effective.

  769. I purchased this kit to use on myself in lieu of having to go to the salon and drop $70 each time I wanted a bikini wax. It can be messy, but if you make sure the wax is the right temperature (think the consistency of honey) then it isn't as messy. Giving yourself a bikini wax is tricky regardless! I have noticed, though that the quality of the wax has declined the more I use it. There is a TON of wax in this kit. I have used it probably 5 times so far, but each time the wax becomes more difficult to use. Getting the consistency correct has become harder. That said it is still effective and I am glad I made this purchase. Definitely use the gel and oil that is included in the kit. it will make the entire process much easier. For those that have complained about in gown hairs...that has nothing to do with the wax and everything to do with the fact that our bodies are meant to have hair down there! If in grown hairs is an issue then you need to exfoliate when you shower.

  780. A friend of mine got me hooked on Brazilian waxes and living in a warm climate I could never got back! I am in shorts and bathing suits so much the waxes were amazing. However, $50-$70 including tip to get it done at a wax center was eating up my budget! At the cost of this kit, it paid for itself and I probably have up to four more waxes worth left! AMAZING!<br /><br />Upon arrival, shipping was fast. The kit comes in a box with cd, hard wax, cardboard cut out, pre-wax oil, post soothing gel, warmer and wax sticks. This kit is a hard wax kit therefore there are no strips, which is better in my opinion. I watched the video was was helpful (explicit but hey it's as real as it gets with a braziillian right??). I placed the wax into the cardboard cut out provided and placed wax in warmer set on high. * I highly suggest using the cardboard cut out as it helped with mess! No wax dripped into the warmer itself and stayed nicely in the wax container.* The wax was then melted and I turned the wax down to LOW for about 30 minutes. After that I went to town and cleared most hair down there. What I found difficult was technique if anything. The wax did not hurt and was actually better than going to get it done professionally. Keep in mind that if you are a first time it will hurt, come on, it's a brazillian. However as I have been getting waxes for almost a year, my hair is more fine. However, knowing what the right temperature of the wax is is just going to take time, practice and experience. Even on low the wax was too how to immediately dip in and place on body/hair. You must twirl the stick as directed in video to cool for 5 seconds and then place thick on your body. For me, overall the pain was not bad, I took a tylenol before the wax and a hot shower to open pores. The only trouble was getting the technique right after a few strips and then it was smooth sailing. It took me approximately 1.5 hours but for my first time it was much longer still adjusting to the technique. I will be continuing these waxes on my own and SAVING money from now on! So happy I did this, I feel so proud of myself because i'm saving so much money! To imagine I spent 50-70 a wax and now I only have to replenish my supplies! It is a must try! If it doesn't work out you could at least use the kit to wax your legs or another less painful area. Worth Trying.
  781. This product is great came exactly like the picture and it gives you a CD on how to wax. Defiantly Recommend.!!
  782. So I was excited to get this product because I've been on Themis DIY binge, realizing I can do whatever I'm paying another person to do. So with that said, I'm SO HAPPY with this product!<br /><br />1. It's easy and the hard wax doesn't hurt as much as the strips.<br />2. I prepared myself for a mess so I put a towel down, paper towel and cotton balls next to me.<br />3. I can't believe I've paid another person to do this.<br />6. It took almost a hour and a half with job help but it's worth saving $60-$100 a month!<br /><br />My girls are coming to try it after I sent them the final results. Don't judge, I was to excited abd shocked and had to share this!<br /><br />Buy buy buy! :)
  783. I'm giving this kit 3 stars mainly because it was my first time with this type of kit and I would like to think that was part of the problem. First of all, my instructions came in French and Spanish, but not English. The ingredients were in English, but not the instructions, so I assume there was a page or two missing from my instruction booklet. I was able to go online and find these easily so it wasn't a big deal, just a disappointing way to start with a new product. Next, it took 45 minutes for the wax to even *begin* melting, so I gave it 15 more minutes for a total of one hour of warm up time - this is much more time than recommended, but obviously I couldn't do anything with a solid block of wax so I had to wait. After an hour, the edges had melted so I started there. But the part of the wax that was melted must have been too hot (while most of the wax was still a solid block), as it was very drippy. At first it wouldn't stick to the skin at all so I tried another small area. This time, it applied fine, but wouldn't peel off. It dried on and was a major pain to remove as I had to do it tiny sections at a time. It did, however, rip the hair out as I was finally able to get the wax off. It also ruined my manicure.<br />I expect to try again, but it will be very difficult to tell when the wax is ready if more than half doesn't melt at all while the rest is too hot and runny. Maybe I got a bad warmer. If you have a TON of patience (which I do not), I might recommend this product, but I would really suggest having someone else do it, or wear rubber gloves.<br />I wish I stuck with the Moom wax strips, but since I already have this product and most people love it, I am going to try a few more times.

  803. yes, you can and should do your own brazilian waxing. with the right products, it's maybe 15 minutes. not with this kit.<br />i struggled through this kit first before trying some variables.<br /><br />first, the heater is cheap. it's adequate, but you'll get frustrated trying to get temp control. mine broke, leaving the two settings OFF & MOLTEN LAVA anywhere on the slider. 5 stars to amazon for the refund.<br /><br />second, this wax is a NIGHTMARE. imagine flinging honey all over your legs and bathroom, then trying to clean it up. that's your life with this. bonus, it will stay gooey and attract dirt and never harden enough to pick off. so it's like having gum everywhere, forever. the 'wax remover' does NOT get it off of your legs.<br /><br />as to using the wax, it's hard to get the right temp, then it doesn't spread, so you get uneven globs and have to WAIT for each section to get hard enough to peel off. but parts of it will still be goo. trust me, it takes too long and is a HOT MESS.<br /><br />this kit will turn you off to home waxing!<br /><br />i replaced it with the satin smooth kit. what a world of difference. even if you stick with this heater, get the satin smooth hard wax, which hardens & peels clean, and you're done with no cleanup.
  804. I have never ever waxed anything, so waxing my hoo-ha was a somewhat unnerving prospect. I wanted to learn however, since 1) I don't want to pay a salon $50 per (embarrassing) visit to handle it, and 2) I'll be on a cruise in a couple months and didn't want to bother shaving while on board. I received the kit last night and a few hours later, I was hoo-ha hair free.<br /><br />I actually thought the pain would be worse. I mean, it was NO walk in the park. Certain areas down there were on fire temporarily, but the pain dissipates quickly. The video that accompanies the kit was pretty informative, but did not dispense the most critical information: How long is the wax supposed to be on your skin before pulling it up? I found, after using it, that it's anywhere from 20-30 seconds depending on the thickness of the wax you lay down. If it's tacky, press it down and wait a few more seconds.<br /><br />The hard wax is perfect. It does not, as purported, stick to the skin. I spent a good 1.5 hours waxing this one area, but now that I know what I'm doing, I expect it to go much quicker next time. (At least cut in half.) I might also get some topical anesthetic for the few parts that are hyper sensitive. (Not needed for 85% of that area though.)<br /><br />Now that I have this kit, I will definitely continue buying the hard wax. Wish it came with a few extra lid guards though.

  808. Before using this product, I had never had a wax done professionally or by myself. So, I had really no idea what to expect. I use sugar wax on my eyebrows, but honestly that's pretty painful and I thought that if people are using this hard wax on their bikini areas, it MUST be better than sugar wax! Well I bought the kit that comes with the warmer. I also bought the cardboard rings that go around the can to keep the warmer clean. The kit comes with a DVD. I watched it, and it seemed doable. I am not a very hairy person, and my hair is fine, too. Anyway, after a pretty easy learning curve, I would recommend this product to anyone who is tired of shaving. I have used it on my underarms, which works phenomenally. I use it to wax my bikini area, and I really can't believe that it doesn't hurt more than it does. (I will say that I mostly just wax the area not covered by my swimsuit, plus an inch or so inward. The most sensitive areas (you know what they are) are tricky, and I personally find it very painful). The pre-waxing oil seems to work great. I do get some ingrown hairs, but bought an antiseptic gel to use immediately after waxing. Then, when that's dry, I use baby powder. Then next few times I shower, I exfoliate and use the gel/baby powder again. The ingrown hairs are much, much better! The real trick is to use the wax when it is not runny at all. It should be \\"gloopy\\". I heat it for a little while on hot, then to extra low. Sometimes I even turn it off for a few minutes. The wax does not need to cool very much before you pull it off again. If you wait too long, it will obviously harden too much. Also, you will learn that you need some \\"lead area\\" (i.e. a hairless starting point) for getting a grip on the wax. So, apply it so the end where you're going to grab it and pull is just outside the hair growth, and that's where you'll hang onto it to remove it. Way less painful that way. If something goes wrong, you always use a small piece of wax from a previous pull, and it will stick to the end you want to remove- like a handle, for generating better leverage.
  809. awesome kit, but i need some practice before i can do it effortlessly. right now it takes a while and a little bit messy, but not as painful as i though it would be! if you are patient enough and want to save money, buy it! it does pretty good job with the hair! ( although my hair grew back in about a week...? but i read somewhere you have to do it regularly then it will be less and less hair, i have dark not soft hair)
  810. HUGE money saver. With practice, you can get professional results. Inner bits and the lowest part above the inner bits hurt the most (at least for me). I had gotten a brazilian in a salon once and loved it, but the price was too steep for me, so I purchased this kit. My first time started off great on top, but was very painful in the sensitive bits. Hopefully the tips below help other beginners.<br /><br />Some tips:<br />* Watch some youtube videos (and/or the DVD) or get it done professionally first.<br />* Use a towel or a beadsheet to cover the area you'll be in.<br />* Have a waste basket ready and no distractions.<br />* Baby powder helps the wax not stick to the skin (I had a little piece of skin get ripped off without the powder - ouch!).<br />* The pre epilation oil not only reduces the pain by more than half, it also keeps the wax as one big piece and prevents it from sticking to the skin. (I apply the wax to oiled skin.)<br />* It can help to rub the wax up and then down the hair growth to capture them into the wax (then pull against hair).<br />* Leave a ridge at the end from which you'll pull (maybe use fingers to massage it out while it dries for better grip).<br />* DO NOT wait too long - once it feels rubbery, PULL. If you wait until it is hard, it will break into pieces (ouch)!<br />* If you're nervous about some hard-to-reach areas, you can use tiny patches and hold skin around it.<br />* Good lighting and mirror really help.<br />* Some people like Captain Morgan pose for hard-to-reach places - I just liked squatting with a mirror. Do whatever works best :).<br />* Advil or tylenol 1-hr beforehand might help (some use anesthetic spray/lotion).<br />* Don't do it 1 week before your monthly or during it (it will be more painful).<br /><br />Cons:<br />* Both lights (red and green) are always lit, so not sure when the temperature is set.<br />* DVD is not very good in my opinion.<br />* Takes long to melt, but no big deal.

By the way don't buy from there if you can help it, it's incredibly overpriced) but realized that I should first look up online for more options (duh) and here is everything you need for less than $35, what a deal! I recommend maybe making or buying some paper collars, although if you try to avoid a mess (it will be messy either way, but you can prevent the worst) you can keep reusing the same collar for quite a bit. Everything should last for quite a few sessions, so it's not expensive at all. Pain wise, I was pleasantly surprised that it hurt a lot less than I expected. I used to use sugar wax and it always hurt a lot, not to mention it would make skin very tender and wouldn't grab hair in some areas properly (armpits for me) I know a lot of reviewers already said this, but make sure to cover the area you're gonna work on because that wax will drip against your best efforts. I recommend something like an old towel, newspaper or cardboard, so you can just throw it away after you're done. The one annoyance is cleanup. Wax that gets stuck is a pain to get off, so be ready for that.
  859. Cheap wax heater. Takes forever for wax to melt
  860. Probably the best purchase I have ever made, especially for someone who likes to do everything on her own this is just amazing, it helps you with everything, and makes your body look amazing and as if you are a professional doing it. Watch youtube videos (a lot of them) and then you will feel like a pro.
  861. Need around 30~40mins to wait for the wax to melt. With the pre epilator oil, helps to ease the pain! It can be quite messy when apply on your skin. I would suggest cover a layer of plastic before start waxing.

  863. WaAY better than running back and forth to the microwave every 5 minutes to reheat wax. Ive been waxing for years, but if I had only known how much simpler one of these little babies would've made my life, I would have invested in this a long time ago. Great product and well woth the money.
  864. Wax doesn't get removed completely and the skin is sticky!

  879. I ordered this kit and have been pleased with it. I am not a professional, but I use this about once a month for my underarm and bikini-line waxes and it seems great to me. I also purchased a can of soft wax and cloth strips for waxing my legs. But the hard wax is great for smaller areas. I don't use the oil or the cooling gel that came with the kit. And I probably won't use the smaller application sticks, since I don't wax my face or eyebrows. But the price was good for the warmer and the hard wax. I will need to order more of those. Overall, though, I think this is a good kit for the general home user.
  880. Just a bit of background on my history as a waxer...hahahaha. I have been waxing my own eyebrows for probably the past 8 years. I've tried another brand of hard wax and the ready wax strips also. I do have to say I prefer the hot wax. I have tried in the past to wax my bikini line with horrific results-I now know it was because I didn't know how important having the hair in that area the right length, not knowing good technique, and letting the wax dry too long. Needless to say it was overly painful and scarred me mentally for a long time lol. I personally hate shaving as it drives me nuts when the hair is growing back and I can never pull it off without razor burn no matter what I do (this is using a clean razor and shaving cream vs hair conditioner and moisturizing immediately after).<br /><br />So now, my thoughts on this kit: (bought just to use for myself)<br />i really really really like it. As I said before I'm somewhat used to the &#34;pain&#34; associated with waxing. There is no such thing as a painless wax on any part of your body, however I do think this kit/product makes it as painless as possible. You get so much for the price, and the instructional dvd is EXTREMELY helpful. They do show a model and her &#34;lady parts&#34; but I found it to be very helpful as you can really see how the technique is supposed to work and it stresses the importance of consistency and texture of the wax, temperature, and how to know when it needs to be pulled off as well as how to do that the best way. It also has tips for reducing pain (using the pre-epilation oil and pressing on the area immediately after hair removal). You can tell it was intended for professional use but it is very easy to understand and I don't think I could have done it without watching the video. The pre-epilation oil most definitely helps to reduce pain.<br /><br />How I use it: The first time I removed everything, for lack of better phrasing. It took me around an hour and a half, but I do think that time will shorten with practice. I sat in my bathroom floor with a towel under me and a self standing mirror directly in front of me so I could see what I was doing. I removed small sections at a time. It really is best to go from the bottom up like the video says so that you can leave yourself a sort of tab to pull that isn't also pulling out hair.<br /><br />I waited a while to review to give feedback on how long it lasts also. I had no hair coming back (except the few that didn't completely come out during waxing, which is normal) for 2 weeks. 2 WEEKS! That is huge, and makes the mostly minimal pain of this worth it in my opinion. It has been very easy to upkeep with shaving while waiting for the hair to grow long enough to wax again. I will definitely be using this again. I love it and would recommend it to anyone thinking of waxing.

FYI wax is sticky. Please disregard her review if you are considering getting this product, she is not very intelligent. Once the wax hardens, it is not sticky anymore. Also, a tip for those of you who will do this yourself (something I unfortunately learned through experience) - if you want the wax to harden completely, make sure you are in an air conditioned room or have the windows open and its not 80 degrees outside. Otherwise it will break and cause a ton of pain to you....

  896. I purchased this because shaving no longer appealed to me. I had never waxed in my life, but since I epilate my legs and underarms I figured could deal with that kinda of pain. I think I read every single review and tried to follow all the advice, which was very helpful at the time. I now have my routine down and it takes me 30-40 mins to do everything! I start off warming the wax, I leave it on low with the lid on. I work out or clean the house, then take a shower (gotta start off clean you know), then proceed to dry myself off, thoroughly. I prep my floor with an old mat. This part I find to be crucial in fast and painless removal, really oil yourself well. I put enough where I'm not dripping but I can definitely scrape some with my nail. I use baby oil infused with shea butter I bought at my local dollar store. Then I just go at it. I start with the sides and make my way down. I'm a fan of the captain Morgan pose. I'm comfortable with having 2-3 strips going so I can pull one after the other. I used to have a mirror for those hard to reach places, but to be honest I find that \\"feeling\\" worked a lot better. If I oil the area well I find that I don't even need to use the cooling gel. Yes, it works that well. After I'm finished I wash the waxed area with my Summer's Eve (another great product, btw). Pat the area dry, put on my clothes and proceed with the rest of my day. I also wax my upper lip and eyebrows, although I did buy the beeswax pot for my facial hair. Great product, has worked so well for me in the last 9+ months (bought May, 2014) and will never switch to another product.

The warmer itself heats quickly, setting it to high and keeping busy for a bit is all you really need before putting it to low to get started. Make sure to observe safety and sanitary concerns, learn about how to prevent ingrown hairs and never rush. I've used it on my bikini area, arm pits (with assistance) and eyebrows with no trouble, all multiple times, and still plenty in the pot.   916. I purchased this waxing kit with Gigi wax warmer and it has been going strong for over a year now. It was definitely worth the small amount of money that I paid for it in comparison to paying a professional for the exact same results.<br /><br />The only negative is the heat settings. The unit has a sliding indicator from low to medium to high. If you leave it directly on the &#34;Low&#34; setting for an extended period of time, the wax will be too hot to use and you must shut it off to cool it. To be able to use the wax, I recommend leaving it at the absolute lowest position without being off.

  918. I bought a smaller microwave version of this hard wax(gigi brazilian bikini wax) to try out and I liked it enough to get the bigger waxing kit but my kit arrived with a broken cap. The brown dome shaped top was cracked with a large piece broken off. Also, the \\"pre epilation oil\\" bottle was slightly unscrewed so that oil leaked out in the box. I haven't tried the machine yet, but hopefully it works like the microwave wax. The microwave wax was amazing. It didn't have a strong off putting scent and it got rid of all the hair with a minimum of pain. I decided to get this kit because I plan on using hard wax from now on instead of shaving. The hard wax left my skin feeling smoother and it got rid of the dark spots left over from shaving. The only downside to the microwave version was that there wasn't anything to keep the wax warm so that it wouldn't re-harden before I finished waxing. That's why I thought the machine would be useful. My advice would be to try an attractive candle warmer first, then you could keep it on a table as a decorative item when not in use 'cuz the GiGi machine is kind of bulky.<br /><br />***EDIT<br />The wax is messier than the microwave version. It works pretty much the same besides that though. The wax melts fast--about 20 minutes after turning it on. Before, I wondered what the \\"collar\\" that came with it was for. Now, I know that you need it because strings of wax get everywhere otherwise. Also, since this wax is more liquid than the microwave version, it's harder to keep the wax from dripping down from where you placed it. I feel like it might pull less hairs than the microwave version too but that could just be that I need more practice using it.   919. I have been going to beauty salon for waxing but after I moved, I have not found the perfect place that does it as good as my old salon. So I decided to get a wax kit and do it myself. If you have done it before, you will know what to expect. I researched for about a month before finally purchasing this kit. And waited another week to gather some courage to start! Here are some tips:<br />1. You know it will be messy, so cover your floors/carpet. Make sure you turn/twirl the wax around the applicator to minimize drip. If you know what you're doing, it will not be that messy after all. The sleeve helps, but I don't think there is a need to buy any extra since it's reusable and you will not have much drip on it if you are careful.<br />2. Have a stop watch/timer! Very important. The instruction says 30 seconds. If it's not dry it will be messy, if too long, it'll be too hard and painful. Stick to the timing. Do one area at a time if you are a beginner.<br />3. We al know which is the worst part if you're doing brazilian waxing. Be sure to hold firmly onto the back skin (you will be peeling towards you, so hold the part of your skin that is furthest from you) to make sure that you the wax peels off and in time. The part of ths skin is very soft and will tend to lift together with the wax.<br />4. Wrap a scarf around your mouth if you need to scream. Feels like a security blanket ;)<br />5. Be sure to have a mirror and a waste bin.<br />6. Putting pressure on your skin with your fingers after the peel realllllyyy helps!<br />It is a painful process, but it's worth all worth it! Glad I bought it!

  947. I used Sally Hansen Eyebrow, Face and Lip Wax for many years, and recently they changed the formula. The new formula is completely worthless, so I needed to try something new. I ordered this kit and am beyond impressed. The difference between professional quality and drugstore quality (even with Sally Hansen's old formula) is incredible. This wax is so much cleaner. It doesn't leave tons of wax sticking to your face after use. Additionally, a little goes a very long way, with my old brand you had to be very heavy handed and slather it on. I really had to adjust my application, because all that is needed is a thin layer of the Gigi wax. Also, once you make the initial investment in the warmer, ounce for ounce this is significantly cheaper. You get 14 oz. of Gigi for about $11, versus 1.25 oz. of Sally Hansen for $7, when you factor in how much less wax is needed for the same result, it's a much better bargain.

I did not experience any abnormal reactions on my skin and on a pain scale of 1-10 it was about a 2. I got upset with effects shaving would have so I wanted to try waxing. Then I applied the pre-epilation oil they have. After I applied that I applied baby powder. I then waxed in sections, the direction of my hair growth. Then RIP. Honestly, it didn't even hurt.   1016. Okay, this review is based solely on the wax itself, not on the other components. As somebody who's been getting hard waxes for several years now, I find this particular wax horrible and extremely painful. Some time ago, I purchased the smaller hard wax kit for sensitive skin (the wax was a light green color) in order to save time and $100 month I normally spent at the salon. I loved that wax, but wasn't happy with the fact that I had to keep returning to the microwave to reheat. So, I ordered this. The heater/lotions/etc. are all great, but the wax leaves a lot to be desired. I have experimented three times with different temperatures and techniques, hoping it would produce better results, but no. One, it doesn't pull out much hair--of course, you should expect to tweeze a few stubborn hairs after a wax, but with what this leaves behind, you cannot tweeze--far too much hair, even after multiple passes. Worse, it tends to break once you rip, leaving very small patches that must be ripped off separately--very, very painful. I'm confident that it's not user error, because I've used other wax varieties with no issues. Perhaps this particular one just doesn't agree with my skin? Either way, I will NOT be using this wax again. I hope to find a jar full of the green stuff I used to use.

  1026. In my naivete, having never been waxed before, I bought this thinking it would be quick and effortless. At first, it was. I had to wait for my roommate to get home and rip it off.   1027. By far the worst, messiest, and time consuming way to remove hair.<br /><br />First, the good:<br />I am a man using this to wax specific areas like chest, arms, etc. This completely removed the hair in the areas i wanted it to.<br />Smells Good.<br /><br />The Bad:<br />Sticks to everything it touches.<br />Leaves clumps of wax balls in hair that i don't want removed.<br />Takes time and many strips<br />Dries too quickly to get an even surface area<br /><br />Here's my situation, like I said earlier i wanted to remove chest hair mainly so i did. It took out most every hair. Hopped in the shower after to clean the excess wax off. Cold shower, hot shower, doesn't matter, this stuff will peel off your skin in wax ball clumps and migrate to other hairs , some that you might want to keep. So i hop out of the shower and realize that i have clumps of wax in hair i want to keep. Spent hours trying to get it all off. I couldn't get hardly any off. Now I'm sitting here writing this review with clumps of sticky wax pulling on hairs i want to keep. It hurts, it's uncomfortable and it's irritating. Before you ask, yes i watched the DVD that came with it and followed the directions to a tee.<br /><br />SAVE YOUR MONEY! SHAVE IT!
  1028. Heated for 3+ hours yet it never reached the right temperature. Soon as it was applied to skin dried up causing serious issues trying to get the wax off my skin, spent days using my nails, towel, and oil to get rid of wax reside, causing red blotches all over my skin.<br /><br />Been self waxing for over 20 years using microwavable products, never had issues other then getting wax on the microwave so I thought this would be a wonderful alternative. What a disappointment!
  1029. Received product fairly quickly, and used it today for the first time. I was very happy with the warmer - Took about 20-25 mins on high to heat wax, I then set it to medium for a few mins and did my waxing. I had no issues with the warmer or the wax. I read a few reviews saying how bad the wax was - with hard wax you need to spread to the right consistency, let it cool slightly and pull it off before it gets to hard. No problems - worked great. I am a very happy consumer.

  1058. So when I received my unit it didnt look like it was new but rather than going through the hassle of returning it, i decided to just try it.<br />I have failed at horribly at home Brazillian waxing in the past, including using the GiGi Microwave hard wax.<br />This stuff works really well. It is easy to pull and doesn't ever get &#34;too hard.&#34; It flexes as you pull which isnt true of all hard waxes. The wax is a bit runny/messy so you may want to invest in some collars though it's not absolutely necessary (the kit comes with one).<br /><br />It took me about an hour to do my arms and my entire area down there. It was amazing! Yay for not having to shell out for Brazillians anymore - the cost of this is even less than one Brazillian wax with a Groupon!<br /><br />TIP - I had some numbing solution from a previous kit and applied that that first - this is a MUST! You need to order this separately, the kit does not come with it. Then use the oil (which is included) right before you apply the wax.

  1060. After reading 1.5 million reviews on this product, I decided to try it because my Wax Pass at European Wax had run out and I was in a quandary of where I was going to go. Since buying the pass, I had moved to a different area of town and I was NOT willing to buy another pass so I could drive 40 minutes plus for a wax!<br />Anyway, I ordered it from Vitamins4Beauty, as they seemed like the best deal. When the package arrived, it was swathed in plastic; I soon found out why: the pre-epilation oil had leaked ALLLLLL over the box. Brilliant. (Of course I had read of this happening before, so it was a risk). The seller told me to send pics of the box to get a partial refund and all, but I haven't heard any thing back. Yesterday I called the Amazonians who assured me that it would be taken care of!<br />Fortunately, someone who had posted a review had said that baby oil or coconut oil can be used in lieu of the pre-epilation oil, so that's what I did. It was absolutely fine.<br />This kit comes with a DVD (which is kind of icky,but I suppose one SHOULD watch it, but if you've been waxed before, you should be fine without it). I did not use the post gel because I felt that more coconut oil and a little silver gel was fine, plus some people said the post gel burned.<br />If I could do it again? I'd buy the wax, the warmer and the popsicle sticks separately (I had to buy more sticks anyway because the kit comes with so few of them.) Yes, you have to use a new stick EACH TIME you dip it into the wax!<br />The best thing was getting it done for myself without any help. Sure it was tricky and messy (and at one point I wanted to just give up and go back to getting it done) but when I was finished, I was amazed with myself. Empowered even.<br />Remember-you MUST use some kind of oil (or it will hurt like a bitch! (I accidentally missed a few spots with the oil). I used organic coconut and it was fine. Just a thin coating of oil, wipe the excess off with a tissue. (Yes, I've readreviews hating the oil because the wax couldn't grab the hair, and my conclusion is that these people gobbed on WAAAY too much oil.)<br />Also, there was some bleeding, but this is probably because my skin hadn't seen hard wax in a long time. So there it is. So, in summary, buy the warmer, the wax, the collar and the sticks. And some coconut oil, if you don't have any already.
  1061. I am almost done with cosmetology school, so I figured it was time I got myself a wax pot. The pot itself works just fine! The only thing I am not 100% happy with is the wax itself.   1062. I have been using soft wax and strips for years and have never been totally happy with the results. Decided to try this kit to do a brazilian on myself for the first time. It does take patience and some good positiong to get the hairs but this wax is so effective. Make sure you have a light, a good mirror and time, rushing will just lead to frustration and make a big mess. So far, i've done a full brazilian, both of my arms, and my face! and haven't even used half of the tub. what a great value! Its already paid for itself.<br />-Make sure the wax forms a ball when you twirl it on the spatula. If it runs off very fast, its too soft.<br />-Do small sections and put enough wax to make a thicker layer than you would use with soft waxes.<br />-Make sure to use the pre epilating oil, it helps a lot! Ripping pubic hair is never painless but this helps.<br />-While the wax cools on your skin, use your fingernail to flip up a small tab to pull. Tap the wax to feel if its set (it will start to look dull), don't let it cool too much or the wax will break off (this can get pretty painful if it happpens downtown).<br />-Any oil will help get the wax off. I use coconut oil (my regular body moisturizer). rub into skin and the wax flakes off easily.

I've now done 3 bikini waxes and 2 lip waxes and still have half the wax leftover. The first time was quite the learning experience. It is quite messy when you are doing it yourself and figuring out the best techniques but hang in there, its worth it! I turn the warmer up all the way to the hottest setting until it melts then turn it down really low and wait. Don't try to rush it when getting the wax the right temperature, it is worth it to not have it too hot that its uncomfortable but not too cool that it dries/hardens quickly.

  1101. I just tried this kit yesterday. I usually get my Brazilian done at a salon, but wanted to try this because monthly waxing was just too costly. My cousin referred me to this kit. She gave me some really helpful tips that I would like to share: (You can basically read this and skip the DVD) -Before you plan on waxing, place the wax in the warmer for at least 1 hour on High to melt it -Once it's all melted, set it on medium so that the temperature is comfortable when you wax -Shower before waxing so your pores are more open, making the waxing easier on you -Bring a tub of ice cubes or an icepack in a ziplock bag, you will want to cold press the strip of wax you've laid to speed up the process -Lay a towel underneath you to keep the area clean, this process gets messy -Grab a cosmetic mirror, this will allow you to point it down where you probably won't be able to see -Leave a &#34;lip&#34; where there is NO hair at the opposite direction of the grain, this will allow you to pull the wax off easier My thoughts: -Love how easy it was to use. Directions were on point. -Messy, but well worth it. This product pays for itself in the first use. -Honestly, doing this myself with the hard wax was the most PAINLESS Brazilian wax I've ever experienced -Only downside, I was mad that the cover to the wax warmer arrived broken in half

  1105. All I can say is WOW. I am kicking myself. For YEARS I have been going to waxing salons (some downtown with terrible parking etc.) and I have wasted hours of my life (last 7 years) making those appointments. Let's see....it takes 20 minutes to get there, 10 to park, 5 to wait for your aesthetician, another 45 minutes to an hour to get your brazilian, 10 min to check out and 20 minutes to drive home. That's about 2 1/2 hours of my life 12 times a year for the last 7 years I wish I could get back. I got this kit in the mail at 6:30pm and ran upstairs to plug it in immediately. (I was done at 8:30pm) I only read enough directions to see that I needed to put the cardboard ring (included) around the wax container before I plopped the whole thing down in the metal heating tub and moved the switch over to high. I waited about 35 minutes before I couldn't wait any longer. I didn't even bother with the DVD. I've watched those ladies at the salon rip the hair off of my nether regions so many times I could do this with the lights off--and I am NO pro by any means. I took one of the smaller sticks and turned the chunk of wax still unmelted in the middle, but the surrounding hot wax was just fine. I then turned the melting pot down to medium, and I believe the secret must be to use the large rounded sticks they use in the salon. I didn't use the ones that came with the kit. I purchased the larger rounded ones and simply:<br /><br />1. dipped<br />2. twirled the medium to hot wax in a ball on my rounded stick (so as not to string it everywhere)<br />3. pulled my skin upward and thickly slathered a perfect bandaid sized wax slather on me over the hair<br />4. tapped the wax until it was cool (it turns a dull color and isn't sticky)<br />5. pulled up a tad bit of the end and (pulling my skin taunt) ripped up against the hair<br /><br /> I DID use the pre-wax oil about 3 minutes before I started, so that may have helped with the pain. BUT on a scale of 1-10 at the salon with 10 being the worst pain ever, I'm usually at a 9 1/2 at the salon. I would say my pain level using this kit.....a TWO.<br />TWO ladies and gentlemen. I'm not EVEN joking. Why have I never done this before? Not to be crude but they say when its your 'time of the month' waxing hurts like hell. Well- its my 'time of the month' and my pain factor is a TWO.<br /><br />Also.....this took me 30 minutes to do a full brazilian. From the time I sat down on the floor with kitchen wax paper spread all around me-- to smooth and bare walking downstairs to tell my husband I'm never going to another salon EVER. That will save us about $75 a month and hours of my life. I'd say the 14 oz. can (I barely used any) will last about 30 waxes plus. Also the redness factor is a 1/3 of what it usually is at the salon. I'm somewhat still in shock that this $30 at home waxing kit just blew my mind. Anyways, I wouldn't recommend it for a 1st timer. Id recommend it for someone who pays attention to their aesthetician while getting waxed and can pretty much mimic her technique.ng the worst pain ever, I'm usually at a 9 1/2 at the salon. I couldn't imagine how much of a pain in the butt it would be to use a microwave waxing kit, since the wax needs to be at the \\"sweet spot\\" temperature for the least painful wax.   1120. This was my very first wax experience ever. It took me 2 hours to do my underarms and bikini area.. :). I could not believe the results, super smooth and small red bumps that went away within a few hours, which i expected given my bikini area is sensitive. I highly recommend this product and make sure to have towels down before you begin. I had a couple of drips in the beginning, mostly on myself though. I am now a hard wax fan!! Oh one last thing, it did take about an hour to melt the wax in the warmer. So be prepared for that your first time with this kit. Still love it!!

  1128. The warmer seems to run a little hot. I have to keep it at low to get the right consistency and it takes forever to heat (hour+). I tried turning it up to melt and then back down but it takes just as long to cool.<br /><br />The wax though is great. Much easier to use and less messy than my previous wax that I used with muslin strips. I like that there is less waste with hard wax. My first time using this I went straight for a Brazilian which I haven't done in years and then only professionally - it was great! Much less painful than what I've experienced in salons. You need to apply somewhat thick layer (or two thin layers one over the other) to fully coat the hair and let cool completely before removing for best results.<br /><br />The pre-epilation oil is key!!! If you don't use it, prepare for much more pain!
  1129. I love this product! I was terrified for what I was using it for being my first time but hey this made it easy! Place and pull that's all there really is to it. A woman posted a tip to use baby oil to remove access wax and yes that works! I did however use the Gigi wool strips with it for me it's less mess and easier to get a &#34;pull tab&#34; but it works great with or without them. O if you by chance get a bit clumping and can't pull it add more on top and redo the procedure and it'll come with it :) also if its your first time like me take a Motrin and use the Gigi relief gel for redness and irritation I swelled a bit due to my area wasn't used to it but day later I was fine. Totally worth it! I bought more for next time!
  1130. I have never waxed myself before and this kit is so perfect! If you had had waxing done and are familiar with the process this kit will help you get those results at home. SO before you throw hot wax on yourself do some research. The instructions included are just ok.
